section.title: Writing and running Lua code
section.para:
Procedures can be defined and invoked interactively, for example:: tarantool> function f1() return 'hello' end --- ... tarantool> f1() --- - hello ...
In the above example, the requests are being handled in interactive mode for evaluation as a chunk of Lua code.

Thus, the request "function f1() return 'hello' end" causes definition of the Lua function which will be identified as f1(). Then the request "f1()" causes execution of the function. The function returns a string 'hello', which gets displayed.
It's possible to execute any chunk of Lua code, not just invoke functions ... tarantool> 1 + 2 --- - 3 ... tarantool> 'hello' .. ' world' -- '..' means 'concatenate' --- - hello world ...
Lua functions could also be called at the time of initialization with a script in a configuration file. An example and discussion of such a script will appear later in section expirationd.
The initialization script can select and modify data.
Another common task to perform in the initialization script is to start background fibers for data expiration, re-sharding, or communication with networked peers.
Finally, the script can be used to define Lua triggers invoked on various events within the system.

There is a single global instance of the Lua interpreter, which is shared across all connections. Any request from a client is sent directly to this interpreter. Any changes of the interpreter state, including global variable values, have immediate effect on all client connections.

However, each connection uses its own Lua coroutine — a mechanism akin to a Tarantool fiber. A coroutine has its own execution stack and its own set of local variables and definitions, as described in the
closure section of the Lua manual.

The CALL request packet contains the command code for CALL (22), the name of a procedure to be called, and a tuple for procedure arguments. Currently, Tarantool tuples are type-agnostic, thus each field of the tuple is passed into the function as an argument of type string. For example: kostja@atlas:~$ cat arg.lua function f1(a) local s = a if type(a) == 'string' then s = '' for i = 1, #a, 1 do s = s..string.format('0x%x ', string.byte(a, i)) end end return type(a), s end kostja@atlas:~$ tarantool tarantool> dofile('arg.lua') --- ... tarantool> f1('1234') --- - string - 0x31 0x32 0x33 0x34 ... tarantool> f1(1234) --- - number - 1234 ... In the above example, the function finds out the type of the argument (Lua 'string' or 'number') at runtime, gets the byte codes if it's a string, and returns the type plus the string or number.

In addition to conventional method invocation, Lua provides object-oriented syntax. Typically this involves the format object-specifier:function-name ..., where object-specifier is acquired as the result of another function invocation, or is the full library-name.package-name.object-name, or is the full library-name.package-name['object-name'], or is the full library-name.package-name[object-numeric-id]. The following example shows all four forms of object-specifier:
tarantool> s = box.schema.create_space('name_of_space', {id = 33}) --- ... tarantool> i = s:create_index('name_of_index', {type = 'tree', parts = {1, 'STR'}}) --- ... tarantool> s:insert{'a', 'b', 'c'} --- - ['a', 'b', 'c'] ... tarantool> box.space.name_of_space:insert{'c', 'd', 'e'} --- - ['c', 'd', 'e'] ... tarantool> box.space['name_of_space']:insert{'x', 'y', 'z'} --- - ['x', 'y', 'z'] ...

When a function in Lua terminates with an error, the error is sent to the client as return code, along with the original error message. Similarly, an error which has occurred inside Tarantool (observed on the client as an error code), when it happens during execution of a Lua procedure, produces a genuine Lua error: tarantool> function f()error('!') end --- ... tarantool> f() - error: '[string "function f()error(''!'') end"]:1: !' tarantool> s:insert{5} --- - error: 'Tuple field 1 type does not match one required by operation: expected STR' ... tarantool> function insert_without_colon(tuple) s:insert(tuple) end --- ... tarantool> pcall(insert_without_colon,{0, 'b', 'c'}) --- - false - 'Tuple field 1 type does not match one required by operation: expected STR' tarantool> box.space[33]:drop() --- ...

listitem.para:
Convert a string or a Lua number to a 64-bit integer. The result can be used in arithmetic, and the arithmetic will be 64-bit integer arithmetic rather than floating-point arithmetic. (Operations on an unconverted Lua number use floating-point arithmetic.) The tonumber64() function is added by Tarantool; the name is global. Example
tarantool> type(123456789012345), type(tonumber64(123456789012345)) --- - number - cdata ... tarantool> i = tonumber64('1000000000') --- ... tarantool> type(i), i / 2, i - 2, i * 2, i + 2, i % 2, i ^ 2 --- - cdata - 500000000 - 999999998 - 2000000000 - 1000000002 - 0 - 1000000000000000000 ...
Parse and execute an arbitrary chunk of Lua code. This function is mainly useful to define and run Lua code without having to introduce changes to the global Lua environment.
Parameters: lua-chunk-string = string containing Lua code, lua-chunk-string-argument(s) = zero or more scalar values which will be appended to, or substitute for, items in the Lua chunk.
Returns: whatever is returned by the Lua code chunk.
Possible errors: If there is a compilation error, it is raised as a Lua error.

para.programlisting: tarantool> dostring('abc') --- error: '[string "abc"]:1: ''='' expected near ''<eof>''' ... tarantool> dostring('return 1') --- - 1 ... tarantool> dostring('return ...', 'hello', 'world') --- - hello - world ... tarantool> session = require('session'); session.delimiter('!') --this means ignore line feeds until next '!' tarantool> -- Use double square brackets to enclose multi-line literal here! tarantool> dostring([[local f = function(key) -> t = box.space.tester:select(key); -> if t ~= nil then return t[1] else return nil end -> end -> return f(...)]], 1)! --- - null ... tarantool> session.delimiter('')!

listitem.para:
To use Tarantool binary protocol primitives from Lua, it's necessary to convert Lua variables to binary format. The pickle.pack() helper function is prototyped after Perl
'pack'.
Parameters: format = string containing format specifiers, argument(s) = scalar values to be formatted.

simplelist.member: b or B — converts Lua variable to a 1-byte integer, and stores the integer in the resulting string,
s or S — converts Lua variable to a 2-byte integer, and stores the integer in the resulting string, low byte first,
i or I — converts Lua variable to a 4-byte integer, and stores the integer in the resulting string, low byte first,
l or L — converts Lua variable to an 8-byte integer, and stores the integer in the resulting string, low byte first,
n or N — converts Lua variable to a 4-byte integer, and stores the integer in the resulting string, big endian,
q or Q — converts Lua variable to an 8-byte integer, and stores the integer in the resulting string, big endian,
f — converts Lua variable to a 4-byte float, and stores the float in the resulting string,
d — converts Lua variable to a 8-byte double, and stores the double in the resulting string,
d — converts Lua variable to a sequence of bytes, and stores the sequence in the resulting string,

listitem.para: Returns: a binary string containing all arguments, packed according to the format specifiers.
Possible Errors: Unknown format specifier.

para.programlisting: tarantool> pickle = require('pickle') --- ... tarantool> box.space.tester:insert{0, 'hello world'} --- - [0, 'hello world'] ... tarantool> box.space.tester:update({0}, {{'=', 2, 'bye world'}}) --- - [0, 'bye world'] ... tarantool> box.space.tester:update({0}, {{'=', 2, pickle.pack('iiA', 0, 3, 'hello')}}) --- - [0, "\0\0\0\0\x03\0\0\0hello"] ... tarantool> box.space.tester:update({0}, {{'=', 2, 4}}) --- - [0, 4] ... tarantool> box.space.tester:update({0}, {{'+', 2, 4}}) --- - [0, 8] ... tarantool> box.space.tester:update({0}, {{'^', 2, 4}}) --- - [0, 12] ...

listitem.para: Counterpart to pickle.pack().
Parameters: format, binary-string.
Returns: (type = scalar) A list of strings or numbers.

para.programlisting: tarantool pickle = require('pickle') --- ... tarantool> session = require('session'); session.delimiter('!') -- this means following commands must end with '!' tarantool> tuple = box.space.tester:replace{0}! --- ... tarantool> string.len(tuple[1])! --- - 1 ... tarantool> pickle.unpack('b', tuple[1])! --- - 48 ... tarantool> pickle.unpack('bsi', pickle.pack('bsi', 255, 65535, 4294967295))! --- - 255 - 65535 - 4294967295 ... tarantool> pickle.unpack('ls', pickle.pack('ls', tonumber64('18446744073709551615'), 65535))! --- - 18446744073709551615 - 65535 ... tarantool> num, str, num64 = pickle.unpack('sAl', pickle.pack('sAl', 666, 'string', -> tonumber64('666666666666666')))! --- ... tarantool> num, str, num64! --- - 666 - string - 666666666666666 ... tarantool> session.delimiter('') -- back to normal: commands end with line feed!

section.title: Package digest
section.para:
A "digest" is a value which is returned by a
Cryptographic hash function applied against a string. Tarantool supports five types of cryptographic hash functions (MD4, MD5, SHA-0,
SHA-1, SHA-2)
as well as a checksum function (CRC32). The functions in digest are: digest.crc32(string) Returns 32-bit checksum made with CRC32. digest.crc32_update(number,string) Returns update of a checksum calculated with crc32. digest.sha(string) Returns 160-bit digest made with SHA-0. Not recommended. digest.sha_hex(string) Returns hexadecimal of a digest calculated with sha. digest.sha1(string) Returns 160-bit digest made with SHA-1. digest.sha1_hex(string) Returns hexadecimal of a digest calculated with sha1. digest.sha224(string) Returns 224-bit digest made with SHA-2. digest.sha224_hex(string) Returns hexadecimal of a digest calculated with sha224. digest.sha256(string) Returns 256-bit digest made with SHA-2. digest.sha256_hex(string) Returns hexadecimal of a digest calculated with sha256. digest.sha384(string) Returns 384-bit digest made with SHA-2. digest.sha384_hex(string) Returns hexadecimal of a digest calculated with sha384. - digest.sha512(string) Returns 512-bit digest made with SHA-2. digest.sha512_hex(string) Returns hexadecimal of a digest calculated with sha512. digest.md4(string) Returns 128-bit digest made with MD4. digest.md4_hex(string) Returns hexadecimal of a digest calculated with md4. digest.md5(string) Returns 256-bit digest made with MD5. digest.md5_hex(string) Returns hexadecimal of a digest calculated with md5.

In the following example, the user creates two functions, password_insert() which inserts a SHA-1 digest of the word "^S^e^c^ret Wordpass" into a tuple set, and password_check() which requires input of a password. localhost> digest = require('digest') localhost> session = require('session'); session.delimiter('!') --this means ignore line feeds until next '!' localhost> function password_insert() -> box.space.tester:insert{12345,digest.sha1('^S^e^c^ret Wordpass')} -> return 'OK' -> end! --- ... localhost> function password_check(password) -> local t -> t=box.space.tester:select{12345} -> if (digest.sha1(password)==t[2]) then -> print('Password is valid') -> else -> print('Password is not valid') -> end -> end! --- ... localhost> password_insert()! Call OK, 1 rows affected ['OK'] localhost> session.delimiter('') -- back to normal: commands end with line feed!
If a later user calls the password_check() function and enters the wrong password, the result is an error.localhost> password_check ('Secret Password') --- Password is not valid ...

section.title: Package uuid
section.para: A "UUID" is a Universally unique identifier. If an application requires that a value be unique only within a single computer or on a single database, then a simple counter is better than a UUID, because getting a UUID is time-consuming (it requires a syscall). For clusters of computers, or widely distributed applications, UUIDs are better.

The functions that can return a UUID are: uuid(), uuid.bin(), uuid.str(). The functions that can convert between different types of UUID are: :bin(), :str(), uuid.fromstr(), uuid.frombin(). The function that can determine whether a UUID is an all-zero value is: :isnil().

listitem.para: Returns: a UUID with type = cdata.
Returns: a UUID with type = 16-byte binary string.
Returns: a UUID with type = 36-byte hexadecimal string.
Parameters: byte-order can be 'l' (little-endian), 'b' (big-endian), 'h' (endianness depends on host) (default), or 'n' (endiannes depends on network).
Returns: UUID with type = 16-byte binary string converted from cdata input value.
Returns: UUID with type = 36-byte hexadecimal string converted from cdata input value.
Returns: UUID with type = cdata converted from 36-byte hexadecimal string input value.
Returns: UUID with type = cdata converted from 16-byte binary string input value.

Returns: true if the value is all zero, otherwise false. The all-zero UUID value can be expressed as uuid.NULL, or as uuid.fromstr('00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000'). The comparison with an all-zero value can also be expressed as uuid_with_type_cdata == uuid.NULL.

para.programlisting: tarantool> uuid = require('uuid') --- ... tarantool> uuid(), uuid.bin(), uuid.str() --- - 16ffedc8-cbae-4f93-a05e-349f3ab70baa - !!binary FvG+Vy1MfUC6kIyeM81DYw== - 67c999d2-5dce-4e58-be16-ac1bcb93160f ... tarantool> uu = uuid() --- ... tarantool> #uu:bin(), #uu:str(), type(uu), uu:isnil() --- - 16 - 36 - cdata - false ...

section.para: Possible errors: The server tries to load the libuuid library when it starts. If the library is not available, which can happen if it was not found when the server was built from source, then require('uuid') returns an error.

variablelist.para:
The json package provides JSON manipulation routines. It is based on the Lua-CJSON package by Mark Pulford.
For a complete manual on Lua-CJSON please read the official documentation.

listitem.para: Convert a Lua object to a JSON string.
Parameters: either a scalar value or a Lua table value.
Returns: (type = string) the original value reformatted as a JSON string.
listitem.programlisting: tarantool> json=require('json') --- ... tarantool> json.encode(123) --- - '123' ... tarantool> json.encode({123}) --- - '[123]' ... tarantool> json.encode({123, 234, 345}) --- - '[123,234,345]' ... tarantool> json.encode({abc = 234, cde = 345}) --- - '{"cde":345,"abc":234}' ... tarantool> json.encode({hello = {'world'}}) --- - '{"hello":["world"]}' ...

listitem.para: Convert a JSON string to a Lua object.
Parameters: string-value = a string formatted as JSON.
Returns: (type = Lua table) the original contents formatted as a Lua table.
listitem.programlisting: tarantool> json=require('json') --- ... tarantool> json.decode('123') --- - 123 ... tarantool> json.decode('[123, "hello"]')[2] --- - hello ... tarantool> json.decode('{"hello": "world"}').hello --- - world ...

listitem.para: Return a value comparable to Lua "nil" which may be useful as a placeholder in a tuple.
Parameters: none.
Returns: the comparable value.

section.title: Package fiber
section.para: The fiber package allows for creating, running and managing fibers.

A fiber is a set of instructions which are executed with cooperative multitasking. Fibers managed by the fiber package are associated with a user-supplied function called the fiber function.
A fiber has three possible states: running, suspended or dead. When a fiber is created with fiber.create(), it is running. When a fiber yields control with fiber.sleep(), it is suspended. When a fiber ends (because the fiber function ends), it is dead.

All fibers are part of the fiber registry. This registry can be searched (fiber.find()) either by fiber id (fid), which is numeric, or by fiber name, which is a string. If there is more than one fiber with the given name, the first fiber that matches is returned.

A runaway fiber can be stopped with fiber.cancel(). However, fiber.cancel() is advisory — it works only if the runaway fiber calls fiber.testcancel() once in a while. Most box.* hooks, such as box.space...delete() or box.space...update(), do call fiber.testcancel(). box.space...select() does not. In practice, a runaway fiber can only become unresponsive if it does many computations and does not check whether it's been canceled.

The other potential problem comes from fibers which never get scheduled, because they are not subscribed to any events, or because no relevant events occur. Such morphing fibers can be killed with fiber.cancel() at any time, since fiber.cancel() sends an asynchronous wakeup event to the fiber, and fiber.testcancel() is checked whenever such an event occurs.

Like all Lua objects, dead fibers are garbage collected. The garbage collector frees pool allocator memory owned by the fiber, resets all fiber data, and returns the fiber (now called a fiber carcass) to the fiber pool. The carcass can be reused when another fiber is created.

listitem.para: Returns: (type = number) id of the fiber.
Returns: (type = userdata) fiber object for the currently scheduled fiber.
Locate a fiber userdata object by id.
Returns: (type = userdata) fiber object for the specified fiber.
Create and start a fiber. The fiber is created and resumed immediately.
Parameters: function = the function to be associated with the fiber, function-arguments = what will be passed to the function.
Yield to the sched fiber and sleep for the specified number of seconds. Only the current fiber can be made to sleep.
Parameters: time = number of seconds to sleep.
Yield control to the scheduler. Equivalent to fiber.sleep(0).
Parameters: none.
Return the status of the specified fiber.
Parameters: fiber = the fiber to be checked -- if this is not supplied, then the current fiber is to be checked.
Returns: (type = string) the status of fiber. One of: dead, suspended, attached or running.
Cancel a fiber. Running and suspended fibers can be canceled.
Parameters: fiber = the fiber to be canceled.
Possible errors: the specified fiber does not permit cancel.
Check if the current fiber has been canceled and throw an exception if this is the case.

Returns: current system time (in seconds since the epoch) as a Lua number. The time is taken from the event loop clock, which makes this call very cheap, but still useful for constructing artificial tuple keys. Example tarantool> fiber = require('fiber') --- ... tarantool> fiber.time(), fiber.time() --- - 1385758759.2591 - 1385758759.2591 ...

Returns: current system time (in microseconds since the epoch) as a 64-bit integer. The time is taken from the event loop clock. Example arantool> fiber = require('fiber') --- ... tarantool> fiber.time(), fiber.time64() --- - 1385758828.9825 - 1385758828982485 ...

section.para:
Example Make the function which will be associated with the fiber. This function contains an infinite loop ("while 0 == 0" is always true). Each iteration of the loop adds 1 to a global variable named gvar, then goes to sleep for 2 seconds. The sleep causes an implicit fiber.yield(). tarantool> fiber = require('fiber') tarantool> session = require('session'); session.delimiter('!') tarantool> function function_x() -> gvar = 0 -> while 0 == 0 do -> gvar = gvar + 1 -> fiber.sleep(2) -> end -> end! --- ... tarantool> session.delimiter('')! Make a fiber, associate function_x with the fiber, and start function_x. It will immediately "detach" so it will be running independently of the caller.
tarantool> fiber_of_x = fiber.create(function_x) --- ...
Get the id of the fiber (fid), to be used in later displays. tarantool> fid = fiber.create(function_x) --- ...
Pause for a while, while the detached function runs. Then ... Display the fiber id, the fiber status, and gvar (gvar will have gone up a bit depending how long the pause lasted). The status is suspended because the fiber spends almost all its time sleeping or yielding. tarantool> '#',fid,'. ',fiber.status(fiber_of_x),'. gvar=',gvar --- - '#' - 'userdata: 0x4133d340' - '. ' - suspended - . gvar= - 181 ...
Pause for a while, while the detached function runs. Then ... Cancel the fiber. Then, once again ... Display the fiber id, the fiber status, and gvar (gvar will have gone up a bit more depending how long the pause lasted). This time the status is dead because the cancel worked. tarantool> fiber.cancel(fiber_of_x) ... fiber `lua' has been cancelled ... fiber `lua': exiting --- ... tarantool> '#',fid,'. ',fiber.status(fiber_of_x),'. gvar=',gvar --- - '#' - 'userdata: 0x4133d340' - '. ' - dead - . gvar= - 257 ...

section.title: Package fiber-IPC — inter-process communication
section.para: The fiber-IPC package allows sending and receiving messages between different processes. The words "different processes" in this context mean different connections, different sessions, or different fibers.

Call fiber.channel() to allocate space and get a channel object, which will be called channel for examples in this section. Call the other fiber-IPC routines, via channel, to send messages, receive messages, or check ipc status. Message exchange is synchronous. The channel is garbage collected when no one is using it, as with any other Lua object. Use object-oriented syntax, for example channel:put(message) rather than fiber.channel.put(message).

listitem.para: Create a new communication channel.
Parameters: capacity-number = a positive integer as great as the maximum number of slots (spaces for get or put or broadcast messages) that might be pending at any given time.
Returns: new channel.
Send a message using a channel. If the channel is full, channel:put() blocks until there is a free slot in the channel.
Parameters: message, timeout.
Returns: If timeout is provided, and the channel doesn't become empty for the duration of the timeout, channel:put() returns false. Otherwise it returns true.
Close the channel. All waiters in the channel will be woken up. All following channel:put() or channel:get() operations will return an error (nil).
Fetch a message from a channel. If the channel is empty, channel:get() blocks until there is a message.
Parameters: timeout.
Returns: the value placed on the channel by an earlier channel:put() or channel:broadcast().
Possible errors: If timeout is provided, and there are no new messages for the duration of the timeout, channel:get() returns error.
If the channel is empty, channel:broadcast() is equivalent to channel:put(). Otherwise, channel:broadcast() sends the message to all readers of the channel.
Parameters: message.
Check whether the specified channel is empty (has no messages).
Returns: (type = boolean) true if the specified channel is empty.
Check whether the specified channel is full.
Returns: (type = boolean) true if the specified channel is full (has no room for a new message).
Check whether the specified channel is empty and has readers waiting for a message (because they have issued channel:get() and then blocked).
Returns: (type = boolean) true if blocked users are waiting. Otherwise false.
Check whether the specified channel is full and has writers waiting (because they have issued channel:put() and then blocked due to lack of room).
Returns: (type = boolean) true if blocked users are waiting. Otherwise false.

listitem.simpara: Returns: (type = boolean) true if the specified channel is already closed. Otherwise false.

para.programlisting:
fiber = require('fiber') channel = fiber.channel(10) function consumer_fiber() while true do local task = channel:get() ... end end
function consumer2_fiber() while true do local task = channel:get(10) -- 10 seconds if task ~= nil then ... else ... -- timeout end end end
function producer_fiber() while true do task = box.space...:select(...) ... if channel:is_empty() then # channel is empty end
if channel:is_full() then # channel is full end
... if channel:has_readers() then # there are some fibers that are waiting for data end ...
if channel:has_writers() then # there are some fibers that are waiting for readers end channel:put(task) end end
function producer2_fiber() while true do task = box.space...select(...)
if channel:put(task, 10) then -- 10 seconds ... else ... -- timeout end end end

section.title: Package session
section.para: The session package allows querying the session state, writing to a session-specific temporary Lua table, or setting up triggers which will fire when a session starts or ends. A session is an object associated with each client connection.

listitem.para: Returns: (type = number) the unique identifier (ID) for the current session. The result can be 0 meaning there is no session.
Returns: (type = number) 1 if the session exists, 0 if the session does not exist.
Parameters: id = the unique identifier of the session.

Returns: (type = string) If the specified session exists, the host address and port of the session peer, for example "127.0.0.1:55457". If the specified session does not exist, "0.0.0.0:0". The command is executed on the server, so the "local name" is the server's host and administrative port, and the "peer name" is the client's host and port.
A Lua table that can hold arbitrary unordered session-specific names and values, which will last until the session ends.

para.programlisting:
tarantool> session = require('session') --- ... tarantool> session.peer(session.id()) --- - 127.0.0.1:45129 ... tarantool> session.storage.random_memorandum = "Don't forget the eggs." --- ... tarantool> session.storage.radius_of_mars = 3396 --- ...
tarantool> m = '' --- ... tarantool> for k, v in pairs(session.storage) do m = m .. k .. '=' .. v .. ' ' end --- ... tarantool> m --- - 'radius_of_mars=3396 random_memorandum=Don''t forget the eggs. ' ...

section.para: See the section "Triggers on connect and disconnect" for instructions about defining triggers for connect and disconnect events with session.on_connect() and session.on_disconnect().

section.title: Package socket — TCP and UDP sockets

variablelist.para: The socket package allows exchanging data via BSD sockets with a local or remote host in connection-oriented (TCP) or datagram-oriented (UDP) mode. Semantics of the calls in the socket API closely follow semantics of the corresponding POSIX calls. Function names and signatures are mostly compatible with luasocket.

Similarly to luasocket, socket doesn't throw exceptions on errors. On success, most calls return a socket object. On error, a multiple return of nil, status, errno, errstr is produced. Status can be one of "error", "timeout", "eof" or "limit". On success, status is always nil. A call which returns data (recv(), recvfrom(), readline()) on success returns a Lua string of the requested size and nil status. On error or timeout, an empty string is followed by the corresponding status, error number and message. A call which sends data (send(), sendto()) on success returns the number of bytes sent, and the status is, again, nil. On error or timeout 0 is returned, followed by status, error number and message.
The last error can be retrieved from the socket using socket:error(). Any call except error() clears the last error first (but may set a new one).

Calls which require a socket address and in POSIX expect struct sockaddr_in, in socket simply accept host name and port as additional arguments. Name resolution is done automatically. If it fails, status is set to "error", errno is set to -1 and error string is set to "Host name resolution failed".

All calls that can take time block the calling fiber and can get it preempted. The implementation, however, uses non-blocking cooperative I/O, so Tarantool continues processing queries while a call is blocked. A timeout can be provided for any socket call which can take a long time.
Most of the functions in the API are usually used in object-oriented style, for example socket:close().
A closed socket should not be used any more. Alternatively, the socket will be closed when its userdata is garbage collected by Lua.

listitem.para: Create a new TCP socket.
Returns: (type = userdata) a new socket, or nil.
Create a new UDP socket.
Returns: (type = userdata) a new socket, or nil.
Connect a socket to a remote host. Can be used with IPv6 and IPv4 addresses, as well as domain names. If multiple addresses correspond to a domain, tries them all until connection succeeds.
Parameters: host, port, timeout.
Returns: (type = userdata) a connected socket on success, nil, status, errno, errstr on error or timeout.
Send data over a connected socket.
Parameters: data, timeout.

Returns: (type = number) the number of bytes sent. On success, this is exactly the length of data. In case of error or timeout, returns the number of bytes sent before error, followed by status, errno, errstr.
Read size bytes from a connected socket. An internal read-ahead buffer is used to reduce the cost of this call.
Parameters: size, timeout.

Returns: (type = string) a string of the requested length on success. On error or timeout, returns an empty string, followed by status, errno, errstr. If there was some data read before a timeout occurred, it will be available on the next call. In case the writing side has closed its end, returns the remainder read from the socket (possibly an empty string), followed by "eof" status.
Read a line from a connected socket.
socket:readline() with no arguments reads data from a socket until '\n' (line feed) or eof (end of transmission).

Parameters: limit — maximum number of bytes to read. The function reads until a separator is seen, or until (limit) bytes have been read. The default is "no limit". separator list — a Lua table containing one or more separators. The function reads until one of the separators is seen. The default is a Lua table containing '\n'. timeout — number of seconds to wait before returning an error.

Returns: (type = string) A Lua string with data if success, an empty string if error. If multiple separators were passed in separator list, the separator which matched is also shown, as the third part of the return.

Bind a socket to the given host/port. A UDP socket after binding can be used to receive data (see recvfrom()). A TCP socket can be used to accept new connections, after it's been put in listen mode. The timeout is used for name resolution only. If host name is an IP address, socket:bind never yields and the timeout is unused.
Parameters: host, port, timeout.
Returns: (type = userdata) a socket object on success, nil, status, errno, errstr on error.
Start listening for incoming connections. The listen backlog, on Linux, is taken from /proc/sys/net/core/somaxconn, whereas on BSD it is set to SOMAXCONN.
Returns: (type = userdata) a socket object on success, nil, "error", errno, errstr on error.
Wait for a new client connection and create a connected socket.
Parameters: timeout.
Returns: (type = userdata) peer_socket, nil, peer_host, peer_port on success. nil, status, errno, errstr on error.
Send a message on a UDP socket to a specified host.
Parameters: data, host, timeout.
Returns: (type = number) the number of bytes sent on success, 0, status, errno, errstr on error or timeout.
Receive a message on a UDP socket.

section.bridgehead: Example showing use of socket over the Internet
section.para:
In this example a connection is made over the internet between the Tarantool server and mail.ru, then an HTTP "get" message is sent, and a response is received: "HTTP/1.0 200 OK". This is not a useful way to communicate with this particular site, but shows that the system works.
tarantool> socket = require('socket') --- ... tarantool> sock = socket.tcp() --- ... tarantool> type(sock) --- - userdata ... tarantool> sock:connect('mail.ru', 80) --- - fd 22, aka 192.168.1.72:49488, peer of 94.100.180.199:80 ... tarantool> sock:error() --- - 0 - Success ... tarantool> sock:send('GET / HTTP/1.0

') --- - 16 ... tarantool> sock:recv(17) --- - "HTTP/1.0 200 OK
" ... tarantool> sock:close() --- ...

section.title: expirationd -- the daemon that shifts expired tuples to a long-term archive
section.para:
For a commercial-grade example of a Lua rock that works with Tarantool, let us look at expirationd, which Tarantool supplies on GitHub with an Artistic license. The expirationd.lua program is lengthy (about 500 lines), so here we will only highlight the matters that will be enhanced by studying the full source later.
task.worker_fiber = fiber.create(worker_loop, task) log.info("expiration: task %q restarted", task.name) ... fiber.sleep(expirationd.constants.check_interval) ...
Whenever one hears "daemon" in Tarantool, one should suspect it's being done with fibers. The program is making a fiber and turning control over to it so it runs occasionally, goes to sleep, then comes back for more.
for _, tuple in scan_space.index[0]:pairs(nil, {iterator = box.index.ALL}) do ... if task.is_tuple_expired(task.args, tuple) then task.expired_tuples_count = task.expired_tuples_count + 1 task.process_expired_tuple(task.space_id, task.args, tuple) ...
The "for" instruction can be translated as "iterate through the index of the space that is being scanned", and within it, if the tuple is "expired" (that is, if the tuple has a timestamp field which is less than the current time), process the tuple as an expired tuple.
-- put expired tuple in archive local function put_tuple_to_archive(space_id, args, tuple) -- delete expired tuple box.space[space_id]:delete{tuple[0]} local email = get_field(tuple, 1) if args.archive_space_id ~= nil and email ~= nil then box.space[args.archive_space_id]:replace{email, os.time()} end end
Ultimately the tuple-expiry process leads to put_tuple_to_archive() which does a "delete" of a tuple from its original space, and an "insert" of the same tuple into another space. Tarantool's "replace" function is the same as an "insert" function without an error message if a tuple with the same content already exists in the target space.
function expirationd.do_test(space_id, archive_space_id) ...
At this point, if the above explanation is worthwhile, it's clear that expirationd.lua starts a background routine (fiber) which iterates through all the tuples in a space, sleeps cooperatively so that other fibers can operate at the same time, and -- whenever it finds a tuple that has expired -- deletes it from this space and puts it in another space. Now the "do_test()" function can be used to create some sample spaces, let the daemon run for a while, and print results.
For those who like to see things run, here are the exact steps to get expirationd through the test.

1. Get expirationd.lua. There are standard ways -- it is after all part of a standard rock -- but for this purpose just copy the contents of https://github.com/tarantool/expirationd/blob/master/expirationd.lua to a default directory.
2. Start the Tarantool server as described before.

3. Execute these requests:
box.cfg{} a = box.schema.create_space('origin') a:create_index('first', {type = 'tree', parts = {1, 'NUM'}}) b = box.schema.create_space('archive') b:create_index('first', {type = 'tree', parts = {1, 'STR'}}) expd = require('expirationd') expd._debug = true expd.do_test('origin', 'archive') os.exit()
The database-specific requests (cfg, create_space, create_index) should already be familiar. The key for getting the rock rolling is expd = require('expirationd'). The "require" function is what reads in the program; it will appear in many later examples in this manual, when it's necessary to get a package that's not part of the Tarantool kernel. After the Lua variable expd has been assigned the value of the expirationd package, it's possible to invoke the package's do_test() function.

After a while, when the task has had time to do its iterations through the spaces, do_test() will print out a report showing the tuples that were originally in the original space, the tuples that have now been moved to the archive space, and some statistics. Of course, expirationd can be customized to do different things by passing different parameters, which will be evident after looking in more detail at the source code.
